results.headline: Oscar Shorts, Low-Hype and Sweet
results.summary_short: The 10 contending short films — five animated, five live-action — exhibit some virtues that their feature-length counterparts lack.
results.display_title: The 2009 Academy Award Nominated Short Films

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The 2009 Academy Award Nominated Short Films

results.headline: Special Abilities
results.summary_short: Imaginatively filmed by Peter Sova, “Push” has a dizzying, chaotic energy that pulls you along.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Push

results.headline: For Inspector Clouseau, That Diamond Is Forever
results.summary_short: Hoary slapstick routines, invariably rushed, are all there is in “The Pink Panther 2.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Pink Panther 2

results.headline: Capturing History With Video of the TV
results.summary_short: The latest work from the filmmaker, poet, archivist and cinematic avenging angel Jonas Mekas is weirdly compelling and almost unclassifiable.
results.display_title: Lithuania and the Collapse of the USSR

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lithuania and the Collapse of the USSR

results.headline: Restoring a Life
results.summary_short: If you can get past the excruciating title, “Life. Support. Music.” is a blessedly nimble journey from loss to reclamation.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Life. Support. Music.

results.headline: Young Women Forever Stuck at Square One in the Dating Game
results.summary_short: Imagine an action flick in which the hero spends the entire movie chasing the villain without the satisfaction of smashing his enemy to smithereens.
results.display_title: He's Just Not That Into You

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of He's Just Not That Into You

results.headline: Portrait of a Martial Artist
results.summary_short: “Chocolate” is risibly sentimental even for a genre not known for its emotional sophistication.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Chocolate

results.headline: From Spring Break Revelry to Abu Ghraib
results.summary_short: “Memorial Day” moves from clever mock documentary to groan-inducing conceptualism.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Memorial Day

results.headline: 5 Artists Inspired and Shaped by a Place
results.summary_short: “Our City Dreams” is a lyrical documentary about the intersection of location and imagination.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Our City Dreams

results.headline: A Short-Term Affair Leads to Big Questions
results.summary_short: Ambivalence is both the theme of “Medicine for Melancholy” and a crucial element of its curious, ruminative attitudes toward love, race and urban life.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Medicine for Melancholy

results.headline: A Fractured Family in a Crumbling World
results.summary_short: The Filipino movie “Serbis” is gentle, bawdy and at times rambunctiously, ticklishly rude.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Serbis

results.headline: Haunted in Macedonia, With a Wolf at the Door
results.summary_short: Milcho Manchevski’s quasi-religious ghost story, “Shadows,” is an unwieldy hybrid of historical allegory and supernatural mystery.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Shadows

results.headline: Two Bickering Sisters, a Stepmom and an Ominous Garbage Can
results.summary_short: “The Uninvited” sounds like the name of a generic horror movie, which is more or less what it is.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Uninvited

results.headline: Tales of a Spike-Heeled Dialoguer in a Land of Okey-Dokeys
results.summary_short: The flat romantic comedy “New in Town” has no idea of how to play its cards.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of New in Town

results.headline: Vigilante Daddy Avenges Kidnapping
results.summary_short: “Taken” starts in low gear and almost immediately stalls out.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Taken

results.headline: Ill-Fated Romance
results.summary_short: “Between Love & Goodbye” tells of the ill-fated romance between a pair of East Village transplants with 2 percent body fat, zero personality and even less chemistry.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Between Love & Goodbye

results.headline: Grief Leads to a Journey in a World of Whimsy
results.summary_short: Depending on your tolerance for relentless whimsy and unflagging eccentricity, “The Toe Tactic” will make you gurgle with delight or groan with exasperation.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Toe Tactic

results.headline: War Hero and Martyr in the Prime of Her Life
results.summary_short: Roberta Grossman’s “Blessed Is the Match: The Life and Death of Hannah Senesh” documents courage, but steers clear of character.
results.display_title: Blessed Is the Match: The Life and Death of Hannah Senesh

results.headline: The Americans Arrive and Cultures Collide
results.summary_short: “California Dreamin’ ” is a rambunctious, closely observed comedy of cultural collision.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of California Dreamin'

results.headline: Clash of the Monsters: The Origins of a Feud
results.summary_short: “Underworld: Rise of the Lycans,” a prehistory to the first two “Underworld” movies, rewinds to when the werewolves rebelled against their vampire masters.
